Download your application

You will need to sign it in front of a lawyer or JP, then bring it to a magistrates court to lodge your application.

Lodging your application

Next steps for the applicant:

  • Prepare your application You just did this!

  • {{#if userIsAggrieved}}Get{{else}}Help {{theAggrieved}} get{{/if}} legal advice {{#if legalAdviceDone}} Check with your lawyer if you have any more questions now that you have completed the form. {{else}} In some areas there are programs to help people apply for a domestic violence protection order—these include domestic violence prevention programs, application assistance programs or domestic violence services. You can ask at the magistrates court about these programs. {{/if}}

  • Print application You must print the application before you bring it to court. If you are not comfortable printing at home, ask a trusted friend, or try a public library or local business.

  • Attach copies of other court orders If you have any court orders, like family law orders about your children, Childrens Court orders or any old or current domestic violence orders, you must attach a copy to your domestic violence order application.

  • Sign the declaration This must be witnessed by a Justice of the Peace, Commissioner for Declarations or a Solicitor. All magistrates courts have a Justice of the Peace, but you should check what day and time they are available. Search for your nearest JP or Cdec.

  • Lodge at a Magistrates Court Search courthouse locations for your nearest magistrates court. {{#if aggrievedCourtSafetyConcern}}Give the court safety form to the court staff.{{/if}}

What happens after you lodge the application?

{{#if tpoApply}} You will be given a court date (as soon as possible), depending on the court’s availability, to ask for a temporary protection order. {{else}} You will be given a a date to appear at court (usually in about four weeks time). {{/if}}

Serving of the application

Once the application has been lodged, {{theRespondent}} has the right to get a copy of it so that {{respondentTheyKnow}} what has been said and can respond in court. Police will serve the respondent with a copy of the application.

Gather evidence

Begin to think about and collect evidence that you can show a magistrate. For example:

  • photos of injuries
  • statements from witnesses
  • doctors’ reports
  • reports from counsellors
  • text/voicemail messages
  • emails
  • letters
  • social media posts with printed dates.
